ground_truth: Bert takes a seat. Findley has a mischievous look on his face as he brings out a cloth bag and pours out the three billiard balls on the table. Eddie shoots. His red ball ricochets off the shoulder and returns to kiss the third ball. Findley steps up to the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie alone. Findley points to a statue on a table behind the couch. It is a figure of Pan, with horns sticking up through his curly head, and the legs of a goat extending down below his waist. Findley completes a shot, then lays his cue gently on the table and goes to the bar. Eddie, his coat off, rubs his hand nervously. Bert turns his back on Eddie and joins Findley at the bar. Eddie stands helplessly for a moment. Findley pours a drink as Eddie approaches. He reaches in his pocket, then remembers that he gave his money to Sarah. He bounds up the stairs. He bursts into the room, goes past Sarah, stretched out on the bed, and takes the money out of her purse. She is facing away from him but her eyes are open. She listens to him as he shuts the door loudly on his way out. Eddie leaps down the stairs, two at a time. Bert eyes Eddie with controlled rage as the two get ready to play again. A game has just ended as Sarah quietly descends the stairs. She stands at the rail, listening. Bert sits with his shoes up on the couch. Eddie turns and sees her. His eyes are shut tight; his balled-up fists rub against his temples. A stunned Eddie moves to the billiard table. Defeated, Sarah turns and goes up the stairs. The men return to the table to continue their game. Bert, deeply satisfied, puts on his coat and sits to watch the action. A shaken Findley flops into a leather swivel chair. A bucket of iced champagne sits on the desk, ready to be emptied. Findley puffs on his cigarette as he looks at the impatient face of Bert, slouching in the chair across from him. Eddie leans against a wall nearby. He is quiet, morose. Eddie moves to leave. Findley and Bert watch him go. Eddie waits for Bert to come down the stairs. Eddie abruptly turns and walks out of the house. Bert watches him for a moment then follows. Bert enters his suite, removes his overcoat, then looks at the door that divides his room from Sarah's. He seems hesitant, unsure of himself. He pours himself a drink and downs it in one gulp, walks to the door, listens, and opens it himself without knocking. Sarah is there, seated primly on the bed.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Bert takes a chair. Findley has a roguish expression on his visage as he produces a fabric sack and spills out the three pool spheres on the surface. Eddie fires. His crimson sphere bounces off the edge and returns to brush the third sphere. Findley steps up to the pub, leaving Bert and Eddie solitary. Findley indicates a sculpture on a surface behind the sofa. It is a statue of Pan, with antlers protruding through his wavy locks, and the limbs of a goat extending below his midsection. Findley completes a stroke, then lays his stick softly on the surface and goes to the pub. Eddie, his jacket removed, rubs his palm anxiously. Bert turns his back on Eddie and joins Findley at the pub. Eddie stands powerlessly for an instant. Findley pours a beverage as Eddie approaches. He reaches in his pocket, then recalls that he gave his cash to Sarah. He bounds up the stairs. He bursts into the chamber, goes past Sarah, reclined on the bed, and extracts the cash from her handbag. She is facing away from him but her eyes are open. She listens to him as he shuts the portal loudly on his way out. Eddie jumps down the stairs, two at a time. Bert eyes Eddie with restrained fury as the pair prepare to play again. A match has just concluded as Sarah quietly descends the stairs. She stands at the rail, listening. Bert sits with his footwear up on the sofa. Eddie turns and sees her. His eyes are shut tight; his clenched fists rub against his temples. A stunned Eddie moves to the pool surface. Defeated, Sarah turns and ascends the stairs. The men return to the surface to continue their match. Bert, deeply satisfied, dons his jacket and sits to observe the action. A shaken Findley collapses into a leather rotating seat. A pail of chilled champagne sits on the desk, ready to be emptied. Findley puffs on his smoke as he looks at the restless visage of Bert, slouching in the seat across from him. Eddie leans against a partition nearby. He is quiet, sullen. Eddie moves to depart. Findley and Bert watch him go. Eddie waits for Bert to descend the stairs. Eddie abruptly turns and exits the dwelling. Bert watches him for an instant then follows. Bert enters his suite, removes his topcoat, then looks at the portal that divides his chamber from Sarah's. He seems hesitant, unsure of himself. He pours himself a beverage and downs it in one gulp, walks to the portal, listens, and opens it himself without knocking. Sarah is there, seated demurely on the bed.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Bert is seated. A mischievous look is worn by Findley on his face as a cloth bag is brought out by him, and the three billiard balls are poured out on the table. A shot is made by Eddie. The shoulder is ricocheted off by his red ball, and the third ball is kissed. The bar is approached by Findley, leaving Bert and Eddie alone. A statue on a table behind the couch is pointed to by Findley. It depicts a figure of Pan, with horns sticking up through his curly head, and the legs of a goat extending down below his waist. A shot is completed by Findley, then his cue is laid gently on the table by him, and he goes to the bar. Eddie, his coat off, nervously rubs his hand. Eddie is turned away from by Bert as he joins Findley at the bar. A moment of helplessness is experienced by Eddie as he stands. A drink is poured by Findley as Eddie approaches. His pocket is reached into, then he remembers that Sarah was given his money by him. The stairs are bounded up by him. The room is burst into by him, and Sarah, stretched out on the bed, is passed by him, with the money being taken out of her purse by him. She faces away from him, but open eyes are kept by her. She listens to the sound of the door being shut loudly by him on his way out. The stairs are leaped down by Eddie, two at a time. Eddie is eyed by Bert with controlled rage as the two are readied to play again. A game is just ended by them as Sarah is quietly descending the stairs. She stands at the rail, listening. The couch has Bert sitting on it with his shoes up. Sarah is seen by Eddie as he turns. His eyes are shut tight; fists balled up are rubbed against his temples by him. The billiard table is moved to by a stunned Eddie. Defeated, Sarah turns and goes up the stairs. The table is returned to by the men to continue their game. Bert, deeply satisfied, has his coat put on and sits to watch the action. A shaken Findley is flopped into a leather swivel chair. A bucket of iced champagne is set on the desk, ready to be emptied. A cigarette is puffed on by Findley as the impatient face of Bert, slouching in the chair across from him, is looked at by him. A wall nearby is leaned against by Eddie. He is quiet, morose. The decision to leave is made by Eddie. Findley and Bert watch him go. Eddie waits for Bert to come down the stairs. An abrupt turn is made by Eddie as the house is left by him. Eddie is watched by Bert for a moment, then he follows. His suite is entered by Bert, his overcoat is removed by him, and he looks at the door that divides his room from Sarah's. He seems hesitant, unsure of himself. A drink is poured by him and downed in one gulp, and the door is walked to, listened to, and opened by him without knocking. Sarah is there, seated primly on the bed.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Bert sits down as Findley, with a mischievous look, pours three billiard balls from a cloth bag onto the table. Eddie's red ball ricochets and kisses the third ball. Findley heads to the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie alone, and points to a statue of Pan with goat legs and horns. After completing a shot, Findley lays his cue on the table and goes to the bar. Eddie, coat off, nervously rubs his hand. Bert turns away from Eddie and joins Findley. Eddie stands helplessly, then approaches as Findley pours a drink. Remembering he gave his money to Sarah, Eddie rushes upstairs, takes money from her purse, and leaves loudly. Eddie leaps down the stairs, and Bert eyes him with controlled rage as they prepare to play again. Sarah quietly descends the stairs, listening. Bert sits with his shoes on the couch. Eddie sees her, eyes shut tight, fists rubbing his temples. A stunned Eddie moves to the billiard table. Defeated, Sarah goes upstairs. The men resume their game. Bert, satisfied, puts on his coat and watches. A shaken Findley flops into a chair. A bucket of iced champagne sits ready. Findley puffs on a cigarette, looking at Bert, who slouches impatiently. Eddie, quiet and morose, leans against a wall, then moves to leave. Findley and Bert watch him go. Eddie waits for Bert, then abruptly leaves the house. Bert follows, enters his suite, removes his overcoat, and hesitantly looks at the door to Sarah's room. He pours a drink, downs it, listens at the door, and opens it without knocking. Sarah sits primly on the bed.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Bert sits as Findley, mischievous, pours three billiard balls from a bag. Eddie's red ball ricochets and kisses the third ball. Findley points to a Pan statue, completes a shot, and goes to the bar. Eddie, coat off, nervously rubs his hand. Bert joins Findley, leaving Eddie momentarily helpless. Findley pours a drink as Eddie, remembering he gave his money to Sarah, rushes upstairs, retrieves it from her purse, and exits loudly. Eddie descends quickly, and Bert eyes him with controlled rage as they prepare to play again. Sarah quietly listens from the stairs. Bert sits with his shoes up, and Eddie, eyes shut, rubs his temples. Defeated, Sarah retreats upstairs. The men resume their game. Bert, satisfied, watches as Findley flops into a chair. A champagne bucket sits ready. Findley smokes, observing Bert's impatience. Eddie, morose, leans against a wall, then leaves. Findley and Bert watch him go. Eddie waits for Bert, then exits the house. Bert follows, enters his suite, removes his coat, and hesitantly approaches the door to Sarah's room. He pours a drink, listens, and opens the door to find Sarah seated on the bed.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Bert slowly takes a seat, settling into his spot. Findley, with a mischievous glint in his eyes, reaches into a cloth bag and dramatically pours out three billiard balls onto the table, setting the stage for the game. Eddie takes his shot, and his red ball skillfully ricochets off the shoulder, elegantly returning to make contact with the third ball. Findley, with a casual air, steps up to the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie alone to continue their game. He gestures toward a statue on a table positioned behind the couch. The statue is a striking figure of Pan, complete with horns protruding through his curly hair and the legs of a goat extending down below his waist, adding an air of mythological intrigue to the room. 

Findley completes his shot with precision, then gently lays his cue on the table before making his way to the bar. Eddie, having removed his coat, nervously rubs his hand, a sign of his growing anxiety. Bert, turning his back on Eddie, decides to join Findley at the bar, leaving Eddie standing there, momentarily helpless. As Eddie approaches, Findley pours a drink, and Eddie reaches into his pocket, only to remember that he had given his money to Sarah. With urgency, he bounds up the stairs, taking them two at a time. He bursts into the room, moving past Sarah, who is stretched out on the bed, and retrieves the money from her purse. Although she is facing away from him, her eyes are open, and she listens intently as he shuts the door loudly on his way out. 

Eddie leaps down the stairs, taking them two at a time once more. Bert watches Eddie with controlled rage simmering beneath the surface as they prepare to play again. A game has just concluded as Sarah quietly descends the stairs, standing at the rail, listening intently to the unfolding events. Bert sits with his shoes propped up on the couch, exuding a sense of casual confidence. Eddie turns and sees her, his eyes shut tight, and his balled-up fists rub against his temples in frustration. A stunned Eddie moves toward the billiard table, while a defeated Sarah turns and ascends the stairs once more. The men return to the table, ready to continue their game. Bert, deeply satisfied with the proceedings, puts on his coat and sits back to watch the action unfold. 

A shaken Findley flops into a leather swivel chair, clearly affected by the tension in the room. A bucket of iced champagne sits on the desk, waiting to be emptied in celebration or consolation. Findley puffs on his cigarette, casting a glance at Bert, who sits slouching in the chair across from him, his face marked by impatience. Eddie leans against a nearby wall, quiet and morose, lost in his thoughts. Eddie makes a move to leave, and Findley and Bert watch him go, their eyes following his every step. Eddie pauses, waiting for Bert to come down the stairs, but then abruptly turns and walks out of the house, leaving the tension behind. Bert watches him for a moment, then decides to follow. 

Bert enters his suite, removes his overcoat, and looks at the door that separates his room from Sarah's. He hesitates, appearing unsure of himself, before pouring himself a drink and downing it in one swift gulp. Gathering his resolve, he walks to the door, listens for a moment, and then opens it without knocking. Inside, Sarah is seated primly on the bed, her posture composed and her expression unreadable.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Bert, moving with deliberate slowness, carefully takes a seat, settling himself into his chosen spot. Findley, displaying a playful yet mischievous glint in his lively eyes, reaches into a cloth bag and, with a flair for the dramatic, pours out three billiard balls onto the surface of the table, effectively setting the stage for the unfolding game. Eddie steps forward to take his shot, and his red ball skillfully ricochets off the shoulder, elegantly making its way back to connect with the third ball. Findley, maintaining a casual demeanor, then steps up to the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie alone at the table to continue their ongoing game. With a sweeping gesture, he points toward a statue prominently displayed on a table situated behind the couch. The statue is an impressive figure of Pan, complete with horns protruding stylishly through his curly locks and the goat-like legs extending below his waist, adding a layer of mythological intrigue to the room's atmosphere.

Having completed his shot with precise accuracy, Findley gently places his cue on the table before making his way over to the bar area. Meanwhile, Eddie, having already removed his coat, nervously rubs his hands together, a visible sign of his escalating anxiety. Bert, turning his back to Eddie, decides to join Findley at the bar, which leaves Eddie standing there momentarily, enveloped in a sense of helplessness. As Eddie approaches, Findley proceeds to pour a drink, and Eddie, reaching into his pocket, suddenly recalls that he had already given his money to Sarah. With a sense of urgency, he bounds up the flight of stairs, taking them two at a time with notable speed. He bursts into the room, moving quickly past Sarah, who is stretched out on the bed, and retrieves the money from her purse. Even though she is facing away from him, her eyes remain open, listening intently as he shuts the door loudly on his way out.

Eddie takes to the stairs once more, leaping down two steps at a time with a sense of determination. Bert watches Eddie with a controlled rage simmering just beneath the surface as they prepare to engage in another round of play. A game has just concluded as Sarah quietly descends the stairs, standing at the rail, her ears attuned to the events that are unfolding below. Bert sits back comfortably, his shoes propped up on the couch, exuding a sense of casual confidence. Eddie turns and sees her, his eyes clamping shut, and his balled-up fists rub vigorously against his temples in a gesture of mounting frustration. A visibly stunned Eddie moves toward the billiard table, while a defeated Sarah turns on her heels and ascends the stairs once more. The men return to the table, ready and eager to continue their game. Bert, feeling deeply satisfied with the proceedings, puts on his coat and settles back to watch the action unfold further.

Findley, visibly shaken, collapses into a leather swivel chair, clearly affected by the palpable tension in the room. A bucket filled with iced champagne sits on the desk, poised to be emptied in an act of celebration or consolation. Findley puffs on his cigarette, casting a sidelong glance at Bert who sits slouched in the chair opposite him, his face exhibiting signs of impatience. Eddie, leaning against a nearby wall, remains quiet and morose, deeply absorbed in his swirling thoughts. Eddie decides to make a move to leave, and both Findley and Bert watch intently as he goes, their eyes tracking each and every step he takes. Eddie pauses, waiting momentarily for Bert to descend the stairs, but then, with an abrupt pivot, turns and walks out of the house, leaving the building and the tension behind him. Bert, watching him momentarily, resolves to follow.

Upon entering his suite, Bert removes his overcoat and turns his gaze toward the door that separates his room from Sarah's adjoining room. He hesitates slightly, appearing momentarily unsure of himself, before pouring himself a drink and downing it in a swift, decisive gulp. Gathering his resolve, he approaches the door, listens intently for a brief moment, and then opens it without knocking. Inside, Sarah is seated primly on the bed, her posture composed and her expression unreadable, as if concealing deeper thoughts and emotions within.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Bert slowly lowers himself into a seat, settling in as Findley, with a mischievous glint in his eyes, reaches into a cloth bag and carefully pours out three billiard balls onto the table. Eddie, focused and intent, takes his shot, sending his red ball careening off the shoulder of the table, watching as it skillfully returns to make contact with the third ball. Findley, with a casual air, steps away from the table and heads towards the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie alone in the room. As he walks, Findley gestures towards a statue on a table behind the couch, drawing attention to the figure of Pan, with its horns protruding through a curly head and the legs of a goat extending below the waist. After completing a shot, Findley gently places his cue on the table and makes his way to the bar. Meanwhile, Eddie, having removed his coat, nervously rubs his hand, feeling the tension in the air. Bert, turning his back on Eddie, decides to join Findley at the bar, leaving Eddie standing there, momentarily helpless. As Eddie approaches, Findley pours a drink, prompting Eddie to reach into his pocket, only to remember that he had given his money to Sarah. With urgency, he bounds up the stairs, bursts into the room, and moves past Sarah, who is stretched out on the bed, to retrieve the money from her purse. Although she is facing away from him, her eyes are open, and she listens intently as he shuts the door loudly on his way out. Eddie then leaps down the stairs, taking them two at a time, while Bert watches him with controlled rage as they prepare to play again. As a game concludes, Sarah quietly descends the stairs, standing at the rail to listen. Bert, with his shoes propped up on the couch, sits back as Eddie turns and notices her. Eddie, overwhelmed, shuts his eyes tightly, rubbing his balled-up fists against his temples. In a state of shock, Eddie moves towards the billiard table, while a defeated Sarah turns and retreats up the stairs. The men return to the table, ready to continue their game. Bert, feeling deeply satisfied, puts on his coat and sits back to watch the action unfold. A shaken Findley collapses into a leather swivel chair, while a bucket of iced champagne sits on the desk, waiting to be emptied. Findley puffs on his cigarette, glancing at Bert, who slouches impatiently in the chair across from him. Eddie, leaning against a nearby wall, remains quiet and morose. As Eddie moves to leave, Findley and Bert watch him go. Eddie pauses, waiting for Bert to descend the stairs, but then abruptly turns and walks out of the house. Bert watches him for a moment before deciding to follow. Entering his suite, Bert removes his overcoat and looks at the door that separates his room from Sarah's, appearing hesitant and unsure of himself. He pours himself a drink, downs it in one gulp, and walks to the door, listening for a moment before opening it without knocking. Inside, Sarah is seated primly on the bed, waiting.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Bert takes a seat as Findley, with a mischievous look, pours three billiard balls from a cloth bag onto the table. Eddie's shot sends his red ball ricocheting to kiss the third ball. Findley points out a statue of Pan behind the couch before completing a shot and heading to the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie alone. Eddie, coat off, nervously rubs his hand while Bert joins Findley at the bar. Eddie, realizing he has no money, rushes upstairs, retrieves cash from Sarah's purse without her noticing, and exits loudly. He bounds down the stairs, where Bert eyes him with controlled rage as they prepare to play again. After a game ends, Sarah quietly descends the stairs and listens from the rail. Bert sits with his feet up, while Eddie, eyes shut tight, rubs his temples in frustration. Defeated, Sarah returns upstairs as the men resume their game. Bert, satisfied, dons his coat and watches the action, while a shaken Findley flops into a chair, puffing on a cigarette. Eddie, quiet and morose, leans against a wall before deciding to leave. Findley and Bert watch him go, and Bert follows after a moment. In his suite, Bert removes his overcoat, hesitates at the door to Sarah's room, pours and downs a drink, then opens the door without knocking to find Sarah seated on the bed.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Bert takes a seat, settling into the plush comfort of the room that exudes an air of refined, old-world charm. Findley, a known prankster among their circle, has a mischievous look on his face as he brings out a cloth bag designed to hold billiard accessories and pours out the three billiard balls, which are standard in games like carom billiards, on the table. Eddie shoots, demonstrating the skill of a seasoned player. His red ball ricochets off the shoulder of the table and returns to kiss the third ball, a maneuver that showcases deft precision. Findley steps up to the bar, an elegant mahogany fixture stocked with an array of fine spirits, leaving Bert and Eddie alone. Findley points to a statue on a table behind the couch, which is a figure of Pan, the Greek god associated with nature, music, and a bit of mischief, with horns sticking up through his curly head, and the legs of a goat extending down below his waist. Findley completes a shot with the grace of someone well-acquainted with the game, then lays his cue gently on the table and goes to the bar. Eddie, his coat off, rubs his hand nervously, a habit he developed during tense moments. Bert turns his back on Eddie and joins Findley at the bar. Eddie stands helplessly for a moment, recalling past losses. Findley pours a drink as Eddie approaches. He reaches in his pocket, then remembers that he gave his money to Sarah, a gesture from earlier meant to show trust. He bounds up the stairs, housed in an ornate manor that speaks of history. He bursts into the room, goes past Sarah, stretched out on the bed in a state of quiet reflection, and takes the money out of her purse, a small floral bag adorned with sentimental charms. She is facing away from him but her eyes are open, aware of the drama unfolding. She listens to him as he shuts the door loudly on his way out, the noise echoing in the silence. Eddie leaps down the stairs, two at a time, driven by urgency. Bert eyes Eddie with controlled rage, reminiscent of their previous heated exchanges, as the two get ready to play again. A game has just ended as Sarah quietly descends the stairs, a witness to the subtle tensions. She stands at the rail, listening to the murmur of ongoing conversations. Bert sits with his shoes up on the couch, an oversized piece from a vintage collection. Eddie turns and sees her. His eyes are shut tight; his balled-up fists rub against his temples, a sign of inner turmoil. A stunned Eddie moves to the billiard table, the ancient centerpiece of the room. Defeated, Sarah turns and goes up the stairs, her footsteps barely audible. The men return to the table to continue their game. Bert, deeply satisfied with the turn of events, puts on his coat and sits to watch the action unfold. A shaken Findley flops into a leather swivel chair, once the pride of a famous designer. A bucket of iced champagne sits on the desk, ready to be emptied in celebration or consolation. Findley puffs on his cigarette, the smoke curling lazily, as he looks at the impatient face of Bert, slouching in the chair across from him. Eddie leans against a wall nearby, enveloped in the shadows of the dimly lit room. He is quiet, morose, reflecting on past errors. Eddie moves to leave, the decision weighing heavily. Findley and Bert watch him go, exchanging a glance of understanding. Eddie waits for Bert to come down the stairs, the anticipation palpable. Eddie abruptly turns, driven by an impulse, and walks out of the house, the door closing behind him with a sense of finality. Bert watches him for a moment, then follows, their paths intertwined yet conflicted. Bert enters his suite, a sanctuary of luxury and privacy, removes his overcoat, then looks at the door that divides his room from Sarah's, a slender barrier marking their separate worlds. He seems hesitant, unsure of himself, a rare moment of vulnerability. He pours himself a drink, the amber liquid glistening in the glass, and downs it in one gulp, seeking courage. He walks to the door, listens, and opens it himself without knocking, a bold move that hints at desperation. Sarah is there, seated primly on the bed, her composure unbroken, the quiet embodiment of resilience.

In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. His eyes are shut tight. his balledup fists rub against his temples. A stunned Eddie moves to the billiard table. Defeated. Sarah turns and goes up the stairs. The men return to the table to continue their game. Bert deeply satisfied puts on his coat and sits to watch the action. A shaken Findley flops into a leather swivel chair. A bucket of iced champagne sits on the desk ready to be emptied. Findley puffs on his cigarette as he looks at the impatient face of Bert slouching in the chair across from him. Eddie leans against a wall nearby. He is quiet morose. Eddie moves to leave. Findley and Bert watch him go. Eddie waits for Bert to come down the stairs. Eddie abruptly turns and walks out of the house. Bert watches him for a moment then follows. Bert enters his suite removes his overcoat then looks at the door that divides his room from Sarah's. He seems hesitant unsure of himself. He pours himself a drink and downs it in one gulp. walks to the door. listens and opens it himself without knocking. Sarah is there seated primly on the bed.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: Bert takes a seat. Findley has a mischievous look on his face as he brings out a cloth bag and pours out the three billiard balls on the table. Eddie shoots. His red ball ricochets off the shoulder and returns to kiss the third ball. Findley steps up to the bar leaving Bert and Eddie alone. Findley points to a statue on a table behind the couch. It is a figure of Pan with horns sticking up through his curly head and the legs of a goat extending down below his waist. Findley completes a shot then lays his cue gently on the table and goes to the bar. Eddie his coat off rubs his hand nervously. Bert turns his back on Eddie and joins Findley at the bar. Eddie stands helplessly for a moment. Findley pours a drink as Eddie approaches. He reaches in his pocket then remembers that he gave his money to Sarah. He bounds up the stairs. He bursts into the room goes past Sarah stretched out on the bed and takes the money out of her purse. She is facing away from him but her eyes are open. She listens to him as he shuts the door loudly on his way out. Eddie leaps down the stairs two at a time. Bert eyes Eddie with controlled rage as the two get ready to play again. A game has just ended as Sarah quietly descends the stairs. She stands at the rail listening. Bert sits with his shoes up on the couch. Eddie turns and sees her. test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Bert takes a seat. Findley has a mischievous look on his face as he brings out a cloth bag and pours out the three billiard balls on the table. Eddie shoots. His red ball ricochets off the shoulder and returns to kiss the third ball. Findley steps up to the bar leaving Bert and Eddie alone. He seems hesitant unsure of himself. He pours himself a drink and downs it in one gulp. walks to the door. listens and opens it himself without knocking. Sarah is there seated primly on the bed.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Frank takes a seat. Martha has a mischievous look on her face as she brings out a cloth bag and pours out the three billiard balls on the table. Lucy shoots. Her red ball ricochets off the shoulder and returns to kiss the third ball. Martha steps up to the bar, leaving Frank and Lucy alone. Martha points to a statue on a table behind the couch. It is a figure of Pan, with horns sticking up through his curly head, and the legs of a goat extending down below his waist. Martha completes a shot, then lays her cue gently on the table and goes to the bar. Lucy, her coat off, rubs her hand nervously. Frank turns his back on Lucy and joins Martha at the bar. Lucy stands helplessly for a moment. Martha pours a drink as Lucy approaches. She reaches in her pocket, then remembers that she gave her money to John. She bounds up the stairs. Lucy bursts into the room, goes past John, stretched out on the bed, and takes the money out of his purse. He is facing away from her but his eyes are open. He listens to her as she shuts the door loudly on her way out. Lucy leaps down the stairs, two at a time. Frank eyes Lucy with controlled rage as the two get ready to play again. A game has just ended as John quietly descends the stairs. He stands at the rail, listening. Frank sits with his shoes up on the couch. Lucy turns and sees him. Her eyes are shut tight; her balled-up fists rub against her temples. A stunned Lucy moves to the billiard table. Defeated, John turns and goes up the stairs. The women return to the table to continue their game. Frank, deeply satisfied, puts on her coat and sits to watch the action. A shaken Martha flops into a leather swivel chair. A bucket of iced champagne sits on the desk, ready to be emptied. Martha puffs on her cigarette as she looks at the impatient face of Frank, slouching in the chair across from her. Lucy leans against a wall nearby. She is quiet, morose. Lucy moves to leave. Martha and Frank watch her go. Lucy waits for Frank to come down the stairs. Lucy abruptly turns and walks out of the house. Frank watches her for a moment then follows. Frank enters her suite, removes her overcoat, then looks at the door that divides her room from John's. She seems hesitant, unsure of herself. She pours herself a drink and downs it in one gulp, walks to the door, listens, and opens it herself without knocking. John is there, seated primly on the bed.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Bert takes a seat. Findley has a mischievous look on his face as he brings out a paper sack and pours out the three marbles on the bench. Eddie shoots. His green ball ricochets off the bookshelf and returns to kiss the third ball. Findley steps up to the kitchen counter, leaving Bert and Eddie alone. Findley points to a painting on a shelf behind the recliner. It is a figure of Hermes, with wings sprouting from his shoes, and the staff of a messenger extending down below his arm. Findley completes a shot, then lays his stick gently on the bench and goes to the kitchen counter. Eddie, his coat off, rubs his hand nervously. Bert turns his back on Eddie and joins Findley at the kitchen counter. Eddie stands helplessly for a moment. Findley pours a drink as Eddie approaches. He reaches in his pocket, then remembers that he gave his money to Sarah. He bounds up the ladder. He bursts into the attic, goes past Sarah, stretched out on the mattress, and takes the money out of her satchel. She is facing away from him but her eyes are open. She listens to him as he shuts the hatch loudly on his way out. Eddie leaps down the ladder, two at a time. Bert eyes Eddie with controlled rage as the two get ready to play again. A game has just ended as Sarah quietly descends the ladder. She stands at the bannister, listening. Bert sits with his boots up on the recliner. Eddie turns and sees her. His eyes are shut tight; his balled-up fists rub against his temples. A stunned Eddie moves to the marble bench. Defeated, Sarah turns and goes up the ladder. The men return to the bench to continue their game. Bert, deeply satisfied, puts on his jacket and sits to watch the action. A shaken Findley flops into a wooden rocking chair. A pitcher of iced lemonade sits on the cabinet, ready to be emptied. Findley puffs on his cigar as he looks at the impatient face of Bert, slouching in the chair across from him. Eddie leans against a column nearby. He is quiet, morose. Eddie moves to leave. Findley and Bert watch him go. Eddie waits for Bert to come down the ladder. Eddie abruptly turns and walks out of the cabin. Bert watches him for a moment then follows. Bert enters his chamber, removes his cloak, then looks at the door that divides his room from Sarah's. He seems hesitant, unsure of himself. He pours himself a drink and downs it in one gulp, walks to the door, listens, and opens it himself without knocking. Sarah is there, seated primly on the mattress.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Bert reclines on the chair. Findley has a mischievous look on his face as he unveils a cloth bag and tosses the three billiard balls onto the table. Eddie positions himself. His red ball ricochets off the shoulder and drifts to nudge the third ball. Findley strolls over to the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie ignored. Findley gestures toward a statue on a table behind the couch. It is a figure of Pan, with horns protruding through his curly head, and the legs of a goat stretching down below his waist. Findley executes a gesture, then places his cue gently on the table and wanders to the bar. Eddie, his coat off, scratches his hand nervously. Bert faces away from Eddie and connects with Findley at the bar. Eddie pauses helplessly for a moment. Findley prepares a drink as Eddie nears. He pats his pocket, then recalls that he handed his money to Sarah. He rushes up the stairs. He bursts into the room, sidesteps Sarah, stretched out on the bed, and fishes the money out of her purse. She is looking away from him but her eyes are open. She observes him as he shuts the door loudly on his way out. Eddie skips down the stairs, two at a time. Bert regards Eddie with controlled disdain as the two gear up to play again. A game has just wrapped up as Sarah silently descends the stairs. She pauses at the rail, observing. Bert reclines with his shoes propped up on the couch. Eddie turns and spots her. His eyes are squeezed tight; his balled-up fists press against his temples. A dazed Eddie approaches the billiard table. Defeated, Sarah pivots and ascends the stairs. The men revert to the table to extend their game. Bert, deeply contented, retrieves his coat and reclines to observe the activity. A rattled Findley sinks into a leather swivel chair. A bucket of iced champagne rests on the desk, poised to be served. Findley draws on his cigarette as he eyes the impatient expression of Bert, slumped in the chair opposite him. Eddie rests against a nearby wall. He is silent, despondent. Eddie turns to exit. Findley and Bert observe him depart. Eddie lingers for Bert to follow down the stairs. Eddie suddenly pivots and exits the house. Bert checks him for a moment then trails after. Bert approaches his suite, sheds his overcoat, then eyes the door that separates his room from Sarah's. He appears indecisive, uncertain. He fixes himself a drink and swallows it in one motion, steps to the door, listens, and opens it himself without hesitation. Sarah is present, seated elegantly on the bed.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The sofa takes a seat. The lampshade has a mischievous look on its face as it brings out a paper bag and pours out the three marbles on the desk. The notebook shoots. Its blue sphere ricochets off the bookshelf and returns to kiss the fifth sphere. The lampshade steps up to the bookshelf, leaving the sofa and notebook alone. The lampshade points to a vase on a desk behind the armchair. It is a figure of an elf, with feathers sticking up through its curly head, and the wings of a dragon extending down below its waist. The lampshade completes a shot, then lays its pen gently on the desk and goes to the bookshelf. The notebook, its jacket off, rubs its paw nervously. The sofa turns its back on the notebook and joins the lampshade at the bookshelf. The notebook stands helplessly for a moment. The lampshade pours a drink as the notebook approaches. It reaches in its backpack, then remembers that it gave its marbles to the kaleidoscope. It bounds up the ladder. It bursts into the room, goes past the kaleidoscope, stretched out on the hammock, and takes the marbles out of its basket. The kaleidoscope is facing away from it but its lenses are open. It listens to the notebook as it shuts the door loudly on its way out. The notebook leaps down the ladder, two at a time. The sofa eyes the notebook with controlled rage as the two get ready to play again. A match has just ended as the kaleidoscope quietly descends the ladder. It stands at the rail, listening. The sofa sits with its slippers up on the armchair. The notebook turns and sees it. Its lenses are shut tight; its balled-up paws rub against its covers. A stunned notebook moves to the checkerboard. Defeated, the kaleidoscope turns and goes up the ladder. The journals return to the desk to continue their match. The sofa, deeply satisfied, puts on its jacket and sits to watch the action. A shaken lampshade flops into a velvet rocking chair. A bowl of iced lemonade sits on the cabinet, ready to be emptied. The lampshade puffs on its bubble wand as it looks at the impatient face of the sofa, slouching in the chair across from it. The notebook leans against a curtain nearby. It is quiet, morose. The notebook moves to leave. The lampshade and sofa watch it go. The notebook waits for the sofa to come down the ladder. The notebook abruptly turns and walks out of the yurt. The sofa watches it for a moment then follows. The sofa enters its cabin, removes its windbreaker, then looks at the door that divides its loft from the kaleidoscope's. It seems hesitant, unsure of itself. It pours itself a juice and downs it in one gulp, walks to the door, listens, and opens it itself without knocking. The kaleidoscope is there, seated primly on the hammock.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Percy lounges in a hammock. Clive has a puzzled expression on his face as he pulls out a velvet pouch and spills out the three marbles on the table. Gerald kicks. His green marble bounces off the bookshelf and returns to nudge the third marble. Clive climbs up to the loft, leaving Percy and Gerald alone. Clive gestures to a painting on a shelf behind the chair. It is an image of Zeus, with lightning bolts shooting out of his curly beard, and the arms of a lion extending down past his shoulders. Clive finishes a dance move, then places his baton gently on the table and wanders to the loft. Gerald, his hat off, pats his pocket nervously. Percy spins away from Gerald and joins Clive in the loft. Gerald stands awkwardly for a moment. Clive mixes a drink as Gerald arrives. He digs in his pocket, then recalls that he lent his money to Martha. He sprints up the stairs. He rushes into the den, skips past Martha, reclined on the sofa, and retrieves the money from her backpack. She is facing the ceiling but her ears are attentive. She absorbs the sound as he slams the door loudly on his way out. Gerald bounds down the stairs, in leaps. Percy eyes Gerald with suppressed frustration as the two prepare to compete again. A match has just concluded as Martha slowly descends the stairs. She lingers at the railing, observing. Percy reclines with his feet propped on the ottoman. Gerald glances and notices her. His eyes are squeezed shut; his clenched fists press against his forehead. A startled Gerald shuffles to the marble table. Overwhelmed, Martha pivots and ascends the stairs. The players return to the table to resume their match. Percy, visibly relieved, dons his jacket and reclines to observe the play. A disheartened Clive slumps into a plush armchair. A jar of sparkling cider rests on the desk, waiting to be served. Clive inhales on his pipe as he studies the anxious expression of Percy, reclining in the seat across from him. Gerald leans against a bookcase nearby. He is silent, sullen. Gerald moves to exit. Clive and Percy watch him depart. Gerald pauses for Percy to descend the stairs. Gerald suddenly pivots and steps out of the cottage. Percy monitors him briefly then trails behind. Percy steps into his quarters, hangs his coat, then gazes at the door that separates his chamber from Martha's. He appears reluctant, conflicted. He pours himself a beverage and gulps it down in one go, strides to the door, listens, and opens it anyways without knocking. Martha is there, perched properly on the sofa.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Bert reclines in a hammock. Findley has a playful twinkle in his eye as he reveals a leather pouch and scatters a handful of marbles on the carpet. Eddie paints. His blue marble glides past the bookshelf and glances off the second marble. Findley dances to the jukebox, leaving Bert and Eddie alone. Findley gestures to a painting on a wall above the bookshelf. It is an image of a centaur, with wings protruding from its feathery mane, and the torso of a lion stretching above its haunches. Findley completes a dance, then places his hat softly on the stool and spins to the jukebox. Eddie, his scarf off, taps his finger nervously. Bert turns his back on Eddie and joins Findley at the jukebox. Eddie stands bewildered for a moment. Findley brews a tea as Eddie approaches. He reaches in his pocket, then recollects that he gave his coins to Sarah. He sprints up the ladder. He dashes into the attic, glides past Sarah, posed on the chair, and extracts the coins from her handbag. She is turned away from him but her ears are alert. She listens to him as he closes the window loudly on his way out. Eddie slides down the ladder, two rungs at a time. Bert eyes Eddie with restrained fury as the two prepare to dance again. A tune has just concluded as Sarah quietly descends the ladder. She stands by the railing, eavesdropping. Bert reclines with his boots up on the recliner. Eddie rotates and sees her. His eyes are wide open; his clenched palms press against his forehead. An astonished Eddie advances to the marbles carpet. Defeated, Sarah pivots and climbs up the ladder. The men return to the carpet to resume their dance. Bert, thoroughly pleased, dons his hat and perches to observe the scene. A disturbed Findley collapses into a velvet rocking chair. A bowl of frozen grapes rests on the bookshelf, ready to be devoured. Findley nibbles on his biscuit as he gazes at the eager expression of Bert, lounging in the chair across from him. Eddie leans on a pillar nearby. He is silent, forlorn. Eddie moves to depart. Findley and Bert observe him leave. Eddie pauses for Bert to descend the ladder. Eddie suddenly pivots and strides out of the cabin. Bert watches him briefly then trails behind. Bert enters his parlor, sheds his scarf, then regards the curtain that separates his chamber from Sarah's. He appears doubtful, uncertain of his intentions. He brews himself a tea and sips it in one swig, approaches the curtain, listens, and pulls it aside himself without hesitation. Sarah is there, perched elegantly on the sofa.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Charlie reclines into an armchair. Maxwell displays a puzzled expression on his face as he unveils a metal box and releases four marbles onto the floor. Polly glides. Her blue marble bounces off the lamp and returns to bump the fourth marble. Maxwell approaches the window, leaving Charlie and Polly by themselves. Maxwell gestures towards a painting on a wall above the bookshelf. It depicts a sculpture of Neptune, with shells adorning his tangled hair, and the tail of a mermaid curling beneath his waist. Maxwell finishes a jump, then places his clipboard carefully on the chair and moves to the window. Polly, her scarf off, taps her fingers anxiously. Charlie turns his gaze away from Polly and accompanies Maxwell to the window. Polly stands awkwardly for a moment. Maxwell blends a smoothie as Polly advances. She reaches into her bag, then recalls that she loaned her watch to Alex. She dashes across the yard. She rushes into the hall, brushes past Alex, sprawled on the sofa, and retrieves the watch from his backpack. He is turned away from her, but his ears are alert. He overhears her as she closes the gate loudly on her way away. Polly skips across the garden, hopping twice each time. Charlie observes Polly with repressed irritation as the pair prepare to race once more. A match has just started as Alex subtly climbs the garden steps. He leans on the fence, observing. Charlie lounges with his boots resting on the rug. Polly pivots and notices him. His eyes are clamped shut; his clenched hands press into his forehead. A bewildered Polly moves towards the marble floor. Deflated, Alex pivots and ascends the garden steps. The players return to the floor to resume their race. Charlie, thoroughly contented, dons his scarf and reclines to observe the contest. A rattled Maxwell slouches into a wooden rocker. A jar of sparkling cider rests on the table, waiting to be opened. Maxwell inhales on his pipe as he studies the restless countenance of Charlie, reclining in the rocker adjacent to him. Polly propels herself against a fence close by. She is withdrawn, pensive. Polly prepares to depart. Maxwell and Charlie observe her departure. Polly anticipates Charlie's descent of the garden steps. Polly swiftly pivots and exits the building. Charlie observes her for a while then trails. Charlie enters his office, takes off his sweater, then glances at the window that separates his room from Alex's. He appears doubtful, uncertain of his actions. He brews himself tea and sips it in one go, strolls to the window, listens, and swings it open himself without knocking. Alex is there, perched properly on the sofa.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Bert sits down as Findley, mischievous, pours three billiard balls from a bag. Eddie plays, his red ball skillfully striking another. Findley points out a Pan statue and, after a shot, joins Bert at the bar, leaving Eddie, who nervously rubs his hands. Eddie remembers he gave his money to Sarah and rushes to retrieve it. Sarah, lying on the bed, listens as Eddie takes money from her purse and exits noisily. Eddie returns downstairs, where Bert observes him angrily. As they resume their game, Sarah descends quietly, watches, then retreats upstairs. The game continues, with Bert satisfied and Findley in a swivel chair. Eddie, morose, decides to leave, observed by Bert and Findley. Bert follows Eddie, then returns to his room, hesitantly opening the door to Sarah's room without knocking, finding her seated on the bed.
